---
title: Datetime
slug: en/v2/api/data/datetime
---

import Badge from "~/components/en/Badge.astro";

`Datetime` is a class for representing dates and times. It corresponds to the [`datetime`](https://surrealdb.com/docs/surrealql/datamodel/datetimes) type in SurrealQL.

### Import

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/decodeonly-datatypes";
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/encodable-datatypes";
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/standard-datatypes";
```

### `.constructor()`

Creates a new `Datetime` object.

```ts
new Datetime(source: [number, number] | string); // decode-only, encodable
new Datetime(
  source?:
    | [number, number]
    | number
    | bigint
    | Date
    | Datetime
    | undefined,
); // standard
new Datetime(
  year: number,
  monthIndex: number,
  date?: number | undefined,
  hours?: number | undefined,
  minutes?: number | undefined,
  seconds?: number | undefined,
  milliseconds?: number | undefined,
  microseconds?: number | undefined,
  nanoseconds?: number | undefined,
); // standard
```

#### Arguments

##### `source`

A pair of seconds and nanoseconds, or a string. If the preset is standard, it also supports inputs like `Date` objects and `bigint`.

##### `year`, `monthIndex`, ...

The same as the arguments to the `Date` class. However, it also supports input of `nanoseconds`.  You cannot provide a `number` after providing an `undefined` argument. This is roughly the same specification as the `Date` class.

#### Return Value

When called via `new`, `Datetime` returns its instance. If the preset is standard, it is also an instance of `Date`.

### `.seconds` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="property" /><Badge variant="decodeonly" />

The seconds part of the nanosecond-precision time. It is read-only in presets below standard. The value is an integer from -2<sup>53</sup>-1 to 2<sup>53</sup>-1, or `NaN`.

```ts
.seconds: number;
```

### `.nanoseconds` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="property" /><Badge variant="decodeonly" />

The nanoseconds part of the nanosecond-precision time. It is read-only in presets below standard. The value is an integer from 0 to 999999999, or `NaN`.

```ts
.nanoseconds: number;
```

### `.valueOf()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="encodable" />

Gets the millisecond-precision time.

```ts
.valueOf(): number;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the millisecond-precision time.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/encodable-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime("2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z");
console.log(date.valueOf());
//-> 1717245296780
```

### `.toString()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="encodable" />

Gets the string representation of the millisecond-precision time. The same as the `.toString()` of a `Date` object.

```ts
.toString(): string;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the string representation of the millisecond-precision time.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/encodable-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime("2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z");
console.log(date.toString());
//-> Sat Jun 01 2024 21:34:56 GMT+0900 (Japan Standard Time)
```

### `.toISOString()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="encodable" />

Gets the string of nanosecond-precision time in ISO format. It is similar to the `.toISOString()` of a `Date` object, but because it is nanosecond-precision, it is stringified up to the ninth decimal place.

```ts
.toISOString(): string;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the string of nanosecond-precision time in ISO format.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/encodable-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime([1717245296, 780123456]);
console.log(date.toISOString());
//-> 2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z
```

### `.toDate()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="encodable" />

Converts to the runtime built-in `Date` object. Note that it becomes millisecond-precision.

```ts
.toDate(): Date;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the runtime built-in `Date` object.

### `.toSurql()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="encodable" />

Converts the `Datetime` object to a string that can be embedded in SurrealQL. It is similar to `.toISOString()`, but it adds the `d` prefix to tell the query parser that the string is a UUID.

```ts
.toSurql(): string;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the ISO formatted date and time with the `d` prefix.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/encodable-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime([1717245296, 780123456]);
console.log(date.toSurql());
//-> d'2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z'
```

### `.getCompact()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="standard" />

Gets the pair of seconds and nanoseconds.

```ts
.getCompact(): [seconds: number, nanoseconds: number];
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the pair of seconds and nanoseconds.

### `.setCompact()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="standard" />

Sets the date and time with a pair of seconds and nanoseconds.

```ts
.setCompact(compact: [seconds: number, nanoseconds: number]): number;
```

#### Arguments

##### `compact`

A pair of seconds and nanoseconds.

#### Return Value

Returns the millisecond-precision time.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/standard-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime(0);
const time = dt.setCompact([1717245296, 780123456]);
console.log(time);
//-> 1717245296780
```

### `.getMicroseconds()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="standard" />

Gets the microseconds of the date using local time.

`.getUTCMicroseconds()` behaves the same as this method.

```ts
.getMicroseconds(): number;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the microseconds.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/standard-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime([1717245296, 780123456]);
console.log(date.toISOString());
//-> 2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z
//                          ^^^
//                           |
//                       +---+
//                       v
console.log(date.getMicroseconds());
//-> 123
```

### `.setMicroseconds()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="standard" />

Sets the microseconds.

`.setUTCMicroseconds()` behaves the same as this method.

```ts
.setMicroseconds(us: number): number;
```

#### Arguments

##### `us`

The microseconds to set. The value is converted to an integer. Note that if the value is not between 0 and 999, the entire time will be affected.

#### Return Value

Returns the millisecond-precision time.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/standard-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime([1717245296, 780123456]);
console.log(date.toISOString());
//-> 2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z

const time = date.setMicroseconds(1_000);
console.log(date.toISOString());
//-> 2024-06-01T12:34:56.781000456Z
console.log(time);
//-> 1717245296781
```

### `.getNanoseconds()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="standard" />

Gets the nanoseconds of the date using local time.

`.getUTCNanoseconds()` behaves the same as this method.

```ts
.getNanoseconds(): number;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns the nanoseconds.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/standard-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime([1717245296, 780123456]);
console.log(date.toISOString());
//-> 2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z
//                             ^^^
//                              |
//                      +-------+
//                      v
console.log(date.getNanoseconds());
//-> 456
```

### `.setNanoseconds()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="standard" />

Sets the microseconds.

`.setUTCNanoseconds()` behaves the same as this method.

```ts
.setNanoseconds(us: number): number;
```

#### Arguments

##### `us`

The nanoseconds to set. The value is converted to an integer. Note that if the value is not between 0 and 999, the entire time will be affected.

#### Return Value

Returns the millisecond-precision time.

#### Example

```ts
import { Datetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/standard-datatypes";

const date = new Datetime([1717245296, 780123456]);
console.log(date.toISOString());
//-> 2024-06-01T12:34:56.780123456Z

const time = date.setNanoseconds(-1);
console.log(date.toISOString());
//-> 2024-06-01T12:34:56.780122999Z
console.log(time);
//-> 1717245296780
```

### `.clone()` <Badge variant="instance" /><Badge variant="method" /><Badge variant="standard" />

Clones the `Datetime` object.

```ts
.clone(): this;
```

#### Arguments

None.

#### Return Value

Returns a new `Datetime` object. If you inherit the `Datetime` class, an instance of that class will be returned.

### Advancement

#### Generic Judgment of `Datetime` Objects

It is recommended to use the `isDatetime` function to determine whether a value is a `Datetime` object, regardless of the preset. This function does not use `instanceof`, so it is useful when the preset of the value to be checked is unknown.

```ts
import { isDatetime } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb";
```

#### Dates and Times Before the UNIX Epoch

The `datetime` type in SurrealDB can be held to nanosecond precision. Because of this, you need to be careful when dealing with it in JavaScript. If you pass a SurrealDB serialized `datetime`, for example `"1969-12-31T23:59:59.999999999Z"`, to JavaScript's `Date.parse`, it will be 0 milliseconds in WebKit, but -1 milliseconds in other browsers (Node.js, Deno, Bun, Chromium, Firefox).

WebKit:

```ts
const date = new Date("1969-12-31T23:59:59.999999999Z");
console.log(date.getTime());
//-> 0
```

Node.js, Deno, Bun, Chromium, Firefox:

```ts
const date = new Date("1969-12-31T23:59:59.999999999Z");
console.log(date.getTime());
//-> -1
```
